00024 //*****************************************************************************
00025 //
00026 // File Name    : 'timer128.h'
00027 // Title                : System Timer function library for Mega128
00028 // Author               : Pascal Stang - Copyright (C) 2000-2003
00029 // Modified             : Hui Dai   huid@cs.colorado.edu 
00030 // Created              : 11/22/2000
00031 // Revised              : 04/28/2003
00032 // Modified             : Shah Bhatti, 1/1/04
00033 // Version              : 1.0
00034 // Target MCU   : Atmel AVR Series
00035 // Editor Tabs  : 4
00036 //
00037 // This code is distributed under the GNU Public License
00038 //              which can be found at http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl.txt
00039 //
00040 
00041 // The Atmel AVR 128 L supports 4 different timers. timer0 - timer4.
00042 // Two 8-bit Timer/Counters (0 & 2) with Separate Prescalers and Compare Modes   
00043 // Two Expanded 16-bit Timer/Counters (1 & 3) with Separate Prescaler, Compare Mode and Capture Mode   
00044 // Real Time Counter with Separate Oscillator ATmega128 ATmega128L
00045 // The driver here only support the Timer0 and the Timer 3
00046 // The support to the timer2 and the timer 1 is basically the same and will be added in the future
00047 // The following are from the original code :
00048 //
00049 //                              Timer0 can be used a number of ways simultaneously.  First, the
00050 //                      value of the timer can be read by accessing the CPU register TCNT0.
00051 //                      We could, for example, figure out how long it takes to execute a
00052 //                      C command by recording the value of TCNT0 before and after
00053 //                      execution, then subtract (after-before) = time elapsed.  Or we can
00054 //                      enable the overflow interrupt which goes off every time T0
00055 //                      overflows and count out longer delays (multiple overflows), or
00056 //                      execute a special periodic function at every overflow.
00057 //                              The other timers (Timer1 and Timer2) offer all the abilities of
00058 //                      Timer0 and many more features.  Both T1 and T2 can operate as
00059 //                      general-purpose timers, but T1 has special hardware allowing it to
00060 //                      generate PWM signals, while T2 is specially designed to help count
00061 //                      out real time (like hours, minutes, seconds).  See the
00062 //                      Timer/Counter section of the processor datasheet for more info.
00063 //
00064 //*****************************************************************************
00065 
00076 #ifndef _TIMER128_H_
00077 #define _TIMER128_H_
00078 
00079 #include "mos.h"
00080 
00081 // constants/macros/typdefs
00082 
00083 // Timer/clock prescaler values and timer overflow rates
00084 // tics = rate at which the timer counts up
00085 // 8bitoverflow = rate at which the timer overflows 8bits (or reaches 256)
00086 // 16bit [overflow] = rate at which the timer overflows 16bits (65536)
00087 
00088 // for 4MHz crystal, which is currently used at the MANTIS project, will be replaced by 8MHZ
00089 // 0 = STOP (Timer not counting)
00090 // 1 = CLOCK            tics= 4MHz  (0.25us)            8bitoverflow= 15625Hz    (64 us)        16bit=  61.035Hz 
00091 // 2 = CLOCK/8          tics= 500kHz(  2 us)            8bitoverflow= 1953.125Hz(512 us)        16bit=   7.629Hz
00092 // 3 = CLOCK/64         tics= 62500Hz(16 us)            8bitoverflow=  244.141Hz        16bit=   0.954Hz
00093 // 4 = CLOCK/256        tics= 15625Hz           8bitoverflow=   61.035Hz        16bit=   0.238Hz
00094 // 5 = CLOCK/1024       tics= 3906.25Hz         8bitoverflow=   15.259Hz        16bit=   0.060Hz
00095 // 6 = External Clock on T(x) pin (falling edge)
00096 // 7 = External Clock on T(x) pin (rising edge)
00097 
00098 // for 32.768KHz crystal on timer 2 (use for real-time clock, supported by the nymph)
00099 // 0 = STOP
00100 // 1 = CLOCK            tics= 32.768kHz(30.5 us)        8bitoverflow= 128Hz
00101 // 2 = CLOCK/8          tics= 4.096kHz (244 us)         8bitoverflow=  16Hz
00102 // 3 = CLOCK/64         tics= 512Hz                     8bitoverflow=   2Hz
00103 // 4 = CLOCK/256        tics= 128Hz                     8bitoverflow=   0.5Hz
00104 // 5 = CLOCK/1024       tics= 32Hz                      8bitoverflow=   0.125Hz
00105 
00106 #define F_CPU 4000000
00107 
00108 #define TIMER_CLK_STOP                  0x00
00109 #define TIMER_CLK_DIV1                  0x01
00110 #define TIMER_CLK_DIV8                  0x02
00111 #define TIMER_CLK_DIV64                 0x03
00112 #define TIMER_CLK_DIV256                0x04
00113 #define TIMER_CLK_DIV1024               0x05
00114 #define TIMER_CLK_T_FALL                0x06
00115 #define TIMER_CLK_T_RISE                0x07
00116 #define TIMER_PRESCALE_MASK             0x07
00117 
00118 // default prescale settings for the timers
00119 // these settings are applied when you call
00120 // timerInit or any of the timer<x>Init
00121 #define TIMER0PRESCALE          TIMER_CLK_DIV1  // timer 0 prescaler
00122 #define TIMER3PRESCALE          TIMER_CLK_DIV1  // timer 3 prescaler
00123 
00124 // interrupt macros for attaching user functions to timer interrupts
00125 // use these with timerAttach( intNum, function )
00126 // timer 0
00127 #define TIMER0OVERFLOW_INT                      0
00128 #define TIMER0OUTCOMPARE_INT            1
00129 // timer 1
00130 #define TIMER1OVERFLOW_INT                      2
00131 #define TIMER1OUTCOMPAREA_INT           3
00132 #define TIMER1OUTCOMPAREB_INT           4
00133 #define TIMER1OUTCOMPAREC_INT           5
00134 #define TIMER1INPUTCAPTURE_INT          6
00135 // timer 2
00136 #define TIMER2OVERFLOW_INT                      7
00137 #define TIMER2OUTCOMPARE_INT            8
00138 // timer 3
00139 #define TIMER3OVERFLOW_INT                      9
00140 #define TIMER3OUTCOMPAREA_INT           10
00141 #define TIMER3OUTCOMPAREB_INT           11
00142 #define TIMER3OUTCOMPAREC_INT           12
00143 #define TIMER3INPUTCAPTURE_INT          13
00144 
00145 #define TIMER_NUM_INTERRUPTS            14

00151   uint32_t uSec;  // microsecond

00154 // initializes timing system
00155 // runs all timer init functions
00156 // sets all timers to default prescale values #defined in systimer.c
00159 void timer_init(void);

00165 void timer1_init(void);
00166 void timer2_init(void);
00169 void timer3_init(void);

00171 // Clock prescaler set commands for each timer/counter
00172 // you may use one of the #defines above like TIMER_CLK_DIVxxx
00173 // to set the prescale value
00179 void timer0_set_prescaler(uint8_t prescale);
00180 void timer1_set_prescaler(uint8_t prescale);
00181 void timer2_set_prescaler(uint8_t prescale);
00187 void timer3_set_prescaler(uint8_t prescale);
00188 
00189 // TimerAttach and Detach commands
00190 //              These functions allow the attachment (or detachment) of any user function
00191 //              to a timer interrupt.  "Attaching" one of your own functions to a timer
00192 //              interrupt means that it will be called whenever that interrupt happens.
00193 //              Using attach is better than rewriting the actual INTERRUPT() function
00194 //              because your code will still work and be compatible if the timer library
00195 //              is updated.  Also, using Attach allows your code and any predefined timer
00196 //              code to work together and at the same time.  (ie. "attaching" your own
00197 //              function to the timer0 overflow doesn't prevent timerPause from working,
00198 //              but rather allows you to share the interrupt.)
00199 //
00200 //              timerAttach(TIMER1OVERFLOW_INT, myOverflowFunction);
00201 //              timerDetach(TIMER1OVERFLOW_INT)
00202 //
00203 //              timerAttach causes the myOverflowFunction() to be attached, and therefore
00204 //              execute, whenever an overflow on timer1 occurs.  timerDetach removes the
00205 //              association and executes no user function when the interrupt occurs.
00206 //              myOverflowFunction must be defined with no return value and no arguments:
00207 //
00208 //              void myOverflowFunction(void) { ... }
00209 
00214 void timer_attach(uint8_t interruptNum, void (*userFunc)(void) );
00218 void timer_detach(uint8_t interruptNum);
00219 
00220 
00221 // timing commands
00222 // timerPause pauses for the number of milliseconds specified in <pause_ms>
00226 void timer_pause(unsigned short pause_ms);
00227 
00228 // overflow counters
00229 // to be documented
00232 void timer0_clear_overflow_count(void);
00236 long timer0_get_overflow_count(void);
00237 void timer2_clear_overflow_count(void);
00238 long timer2_get_overflow_count(void);
00239 
00240 // PWM initialization and set commands for timerX (where X is either 1 or 3)
00241 // timerXPWM_init()
00242 //              configures the timerX hardware for PWM mode on pins OCXA, OCXB, and OCXC.
00243 //              bitRes should be 8,9,or 10 for 8,9,or 10bit PWM resolution
00244 //
00245 // timerXPWMOff()
00246 //              turns off all timerX PWM output and set timer mode to normal state
00247 //
00248 // timerXPWMAOn(), timerXPWMBOn(), timerXPWMCOn()
00249 //              turn on output of PWM signals to OCXA,B,C pins
00250 //              NOTE: Until you define the OCXA,B,C pins as outputs, and run
00251 //              this "on" command, no PWM output will be output
00252 //
00253 // timerXPWMAOff(), timerXPWMBOff(), timerXPWMCOff()
00254 //              turn off output of PWM signals to OCXA,B,C pins
00255 //
00256 // timerXPWMASet(), timer1PWMBSet(), timerXPWMCSet()
00257 //              sets the PWM duty cycle for each channel
00258 //      NOTE:   <pwmDuty> should be in the range 0-255 for 8bit PWM
00259 //                      <pwmDuty> should be in the range 0-511 for 9bit PWM
00260 //                      <pwmDuty> should be in the range 0-1023 for 10bit PWM
00261 // NOTE: the PWM frequency can be controlled in increments by setting the
00262 //                      prescaler for timer1
00263 
00264 void timer1PWM_init(uint8_t bitRes);            
00265 void timer1PWMOff(void);                        
00266 void timer1PWMAOn(void);                        
00267 void timer1PWMBOn(void);                        
00268 void timer1PWMCOn(void);                        
00269 void timer1PWMAOff(void);                       
00270 void timer1PWMBOff(void);                       
00271 void timer1PWMCOff(void);                       
00272 void timer1PWMASet(uint16_t pwmDuty);   
00273 void timer1PWMBSet(uint16_t pwmDuty);   
00274 void timer1PWMCSet(uint16_t pwmDuty);   
00275 
00276 void timer3PWM_init(uint8_t bitRes);            
00277 void timer3PWMOff(void);                        
00278 void timer3PWMAOn(void);                        
00279 void timer3PWMBOn(void);                        
00280 void timer3PWMCOn(void);                        
00281 void timer3PWMAOff(void);                       
00282 void timer3PWMBOff(void);                       
00283 void timer3PWMCOff(void);                       
00284 void timer3PWMASet(uint16_t pwmDuty);   
00285 void timer3PWMBSet(uint16_t pwmDuty);   
00286 void timer3PWMCSet(uint16_t pwmDuty);
